content.text: Once upon a time, in the middle of winter, when the snowflakes were falling like little feathers from the sky, a queen sat sewing at a window.
The frame of the window was made of black ebony wood, and as she sewed, she pricked her finger with the needle. Three drops of blood fell onto the snow that had settled on the windowsill.

The red looked so beautiful against the white snow that she thought to herself, *"Oh, how I wish I had a child as white as snow, as red as blood, and with hair as black as the ebony window frame!"* Not
long after, the queen had a little daughter who was as white as snow, with lips as red as blood, and hair as black as ebony. They named her Snow White.
But sadly, the queen became very ill after the child was born, and soon she passed away. A year later, the king took another wife. This new queen was very beautiful, but she was also proud and vain.
She had a magic mirror, and every morning she would stand before it and say: *"Mirror, mirror, on the wall, Who is the fairest of them all?"* And the mirror would always answer: *"You, my queen,
are the fairest of all."* The queen was pleased, for she knew the mirror always spoke the truth. Years passed, and Snow White grew up to be a lovely young maiden—gentle, kind, and more beautiful
than the queen herself. One day, the queen asked her mirror as usual: *"Mirror, mirror, on the wall, Who is the fairest of them all?"* But this time, the mirror answered: *"My queen, you are
fair, it is true, But Snow White is a thousand times fairer than you."* The queen’s face turned pale with rage. From that moment on, she hated Snow White and could think of nothing but how to be
rid of her. Jealousy gnawed at her heart like a worm in an apple. One day, the queen called for a huntsman and said to him, *"Take Snow White into the forest. I never want to see her again.
Kill her, and bring me back her lungs and liver as proof."* The poor huntsman was horrified, but he dared not disobey the queen. He took Snow White deep into the dark forest.
As he raised his knife to strike, Snow White fell to her knees and begged, *"Oh, dear huntsman, spare my life! I will run into the wild forest and never come back!"* The huntsman’s heart softened
when he saw her tears. *"Run away, then, poor child,"* he said. *"But do not return to the castle, for the queen will know."* And with that, he let her go.
To fool the queen, he killed a young boar and took its lungs and liver back to the palace. Snow White ran through the forest, her heart pounding with fear.
The trees seemed to whisper, and the shadows stretched long and frightening. She ran until her feet ached and her breath came in gasps.
At last, just as the sun was setting, she came upon a little cottage deep in the woods. The door was unlocked, so she stepped inside.
Everything was tiny—the table, the chairs, even the beds—and everything was neat and tidy. On the table were seven little plates, seven little spoons, seven little knives, and seven little cups.
Along the wall stood seven little beds, all in a row, covered with white sheets. Snow White was so hungry and tired that she ate a few vegetables and a little bread from each plate, drank a sip of
wine from each cup, and then, feeling exhausted, lay down on one of the little beds. Soon, she fell fast asleep. When it grew dark, the owners of the cottage returned.
They were seven dwarfs who worked all day in the mountains, digging for gold. As soon as they stepped inside, they noticed that something was different.
*"Who has been sitting in my chair?"* grumbled the first dwarf. *"Who has been eating from my plate?"* said the second. *"Who has been using my spoon?"* asked the third.
*"Who has been cutting with my knife?"* wondered the fourth. *"Who has been drinking from my cup?"* said the fifth. *"Who has been lying in my bed?"* cried the sixth.
Then the seventh dwarf looked at his bed and saw Snow White sleeping there. He called to the others, and they all gathered around, holding up their little lamps. *"Oh, heavens!"* they exclaimed.
*"What a lovely child!"* They let her sleep, and in the morning, when Snow White awoke, she was frightened to see the seven dwarfs staring at her.
But they were kind and asked, *"What is your name, dear child?"* *"I am Snow White,"* she replied. The dwarfs listened as she told them her story—how her stepmother had tried to kill her, how the
huntsman had spared her, and how she had run into the forest. The dwarfs took pity on her and said, *"If you will keep house for us—cook, clean, make the beds, sew, and knit—you may stay with us, and
we will take care of you."* Snow White agreed happily, and from then on, she lived with the seven dwarfs. Every morning, they went into the mountains to dig for gold, and she stayed behind to
keep the house. The dwarfs warned her, *"Beware of your stepmother! She will soon find out you are here. Do not let anyone inside while we are gone."* Meanwhile, back at the castle, the queen
asked her mirror once more: *"Mirror, mirror, on the wall, Who is the fairest of them all?"* The mirror replied: *"My queen, you are fair, it is true, But over the mountains, where the seven dwarfs
dwell, Snow White is alive and well, And still a thousand times fairer than you."* The queen was furious. She realized the huntsman had deceived her, and Snow White was still alive.
She decided to take matters into her own hands. Disguising herself as an old peddler woman, she made her way to the dwarfs’ cottage. When she arrived, she called out, *"Pretty things to sell!
Laces and ribbons, combs and stays!"* Snow White, who had been warned not to let anyone in, looked out the window and said, *"I am sorry, good woman, but I must not open the door."* *"Very well,"*
said the queen, *"but at least let me show you my wares."* She held up a beautiful lace bodice. *"This is the finest lace in the land.
Let me tie it for you."* Snow White, thinking no harm could come from such a kind old woman, opened the door. The queen quickly laced the bodice so tightly that Snow White could not breathe.
She fell to the floor as if dead. When the dwarfs returned home that evening, they found Snow White lying motionless. They loosened the lace, and she slowly began to breathe again.

*"That was the queen in disguise!"* they cried. *"You must be more careful!"* The next day, the queen asked her mirror again: *"Mirror, mirror, on the wall, Who is the fairest of them all?"* The mirror

answered: *"My queen, you are fair, it is true, But over the mountains, where the seven dwarfs dwell, Snow White is alive and well, And still a thousand times fairer than you."* The queen was beside herself
with rage. She decided to try again. This time, she disguised herself as a different old woman and made a poisoned comb. She went to the cottage and called out, *"Combs for sale!
Fine combs for beautiful hair!"* Snow White remembered the dwarfs’ warning, but the queen said, *"Let me just comb your hair. It is so lovely!"* Snow White could not resist.
As soon as the comb touched her hair, the poison took effect, and she fell down as if dead. When the dwarfs came home, they found her lying on the floor.
They pulled the comb from her hair, and she slowly revived. *"The queen again!"* they exclaimed. *"You must not let anyone in, no matter what!"* But the queen was not done.
She asked her mirror once more: *"Mirror, mirror, on the wall, Who is the fairest of them all?"* And the mirror replied: *"My queen, you are fair, it is true, But over the mountains, where the
seven dwarfs dwell, Snow White is alive and well, And still a thousand times fairer than you."* This time, the queen was determined to succeed. She made a poisoned apple—half red and half white.
The red side was poisoned, while the white side was safe. She disguised herself as a farmer’s wife and went to the cottage. Snow White was wary, but the queen cut the apple in half and ate the
white side herself, offering the red side to Snow White. *"It is the most delicious apple in the world,"* she said. Snow White took a bite, and as soon as the poison touched her lips, she fell to the
ground, lifeless. The queen laughed in triumph and hurried back to the castle. When the dwarfs returned that evening, they found Snow White lying still and cold.
They tried everything to wake her—loosening her clothes, combing her hair, even carrying her through the forest—but nothing worked.

They laid her in a glass coffin, where she looked as if she were only sleeping, and placed it on a hill in the forest. One day, a prince was riding through the forest when he saw the glass coffin and the
beautiful maiden inside. He fell in love at once and begged the dwarfs to let him take her away. *"I cannot live without seeing her,"* he said. The dwarfs, moved by his grief, agreed.
As the prince’s servants lifted the coffin, one of them stumbled, and the jolt dislodged the piece of poisoned apple from Snow White’s throat. She coughed, opened her eyes, and sat up.
The prince was overjoyed. *"You shall be my bride!"* he cried. Snow White, who had grown to love him as well, agreed. A great wedding was prepared, and the queen was invited.
When she arrived and saw Snow White alive and more beautiful than ever, she was filled with terror. But her wickedness was punished at last—she was made to dance in red-hot iron shoes
until she fell down dead. Snow White and the prince lived happily ever after, and the seven dwarfs were always welcome at their castle.
